results.title: To kill a mockingbird by Harper Lee. The Miracle worker by William Gibson
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “I couldn’t put it down - hooked on books. Classroom classics”.
The two parts of this video use clips from films of the books to illustrate their themes and discussion points “To kill a mockingbird” depicts life in a small Southern United States town during the depression, through the eyes of a six year old girl whose father is defending a Negro in a rape trial. The novel deals with courage, prejudice and the people and events that shape our lives. “The Miracle worker” tells the true story of the early life of Helen Keller, blind and deaf, through illness and the attempts of a young girl, Annie Sullivan to discipline her and develop her abilities. Teachers notes accompany the video.

results.title: The Diary of Anne Frank. A Separate peace by John Knowles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I couldn’t put it down - hooked on books. Classroom classics”.
Classroom Classics utilises material from film versions of literary works to encourage students to seek out, read, and analyse intelligently books they are studying in class. This video explores “The Diary of Anne Frank” and John Knowles’ “A Separate Peace”. The commentary concentrates on questions of character and motivation.

results.title: Animal Farm by George Orwell. The Grapes of wrath by John Steinbeck
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I couldn’t put it down - hooked on books. Classroom classics”.
Classroom Classics utilises material from film versions of literary works to encourage students to seek out, read, and analyse intelligently books they are studying in class. In this episode two important political novels of the twentieth century are discussed. George Orwell’s “Animal Farm” is a caustic satire about the corruption of idealism. John Steinbeck’s “The Grapes of Wrath” is a powerful novel about the effect of the 1930’s Depression on the American poor. Both novels are analysed in relation to the historic conditions that fed the writers’ art, passion and anger.

results.title: Lord of the flies by William Golding; The adventures of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I couldn’t put it down - hooked on books. Classroom classics”.
Clips from the film versions of these two seminal novels help students understand the plot, characters and essence of the stories. The narrator poses questions which hopefully stimulate the student to think more deeply about the issues tackled in the novels. “Lord of the flies” is described as, simultaneously an adventure story and an exploration of human nature, and good and evil, posing the question “Is human goodness an individual matter?”. “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” could be seen as the true beginning of American literature, and poses questions about freedom, responsibility and individuality.

results.title: Blood on the wattle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
Focuses on the importance and relevance of the Australian Constitution to its citizens. Apart from looking at its origins, and other constitutional models, this kit explores the implications of making changes to the Australian Constitution. Based on one of “Geoffrey Robertson’s Hypotheticals” entitled “Blood on the wattle”. Also includes a post-hypothetical discussion of the Constitution by the panellists.

results.title: The Fast Track
results.creator_credit: Stephen Jones, Ken Chown, Granada International Productions and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
The Minister for Enterprise has a pet Bicentennial project: he wants to build the fastest train in the world, to service marginal electorates on its run from Sydney to Canberra. Businessmen and lobbyists share his enthusiasm for the supertrain but his Department head has reservations which the Press and the Parliamentary Opposition are keen to exploit! Moderator: Geoffrey Robertson.

results.title: Unto Us a Child Is Born
results.creator_credit: John Lander, Ken Chown, Granada International Productions and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
Australian doctors and scientists who have pioneered test-tube baby technology must contemplate a future where men can become pregnant, where parents can choose the sex of their children and where the cure for dread genetic diseases may be found by experiments on human embryos. Geoffrey Robertson’s Hypothetical on Science, Sex and Insemination, filmed in the Great Hall of Sydney University in December, 1985, confronts Australia’s top scientists, lawyers and religious leaders with the ethical and moral dilemmas of tampering with nature, in a television format which has won international acclaim.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Lander, Ken Chown, Granada International Productions and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Does Dracula have Aids?
results.creator_credit: John Lander, Ken Chown and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
AIDS is the most publicised and least understood disease in Australia. This video may help to clear up some of the confusion as the discoverer of the AIDS virus, Professor Luc Montagnier, joins Australia’s most experienced AIDS specialists and community leaders to confront the ethical and social dilemmas created by the disease. Geoffrey Robertson’s Hypothetical on AIDS was filmed on 12th August, 1986.

results.title: In pursuit of the possible
results.creator_credit: Ian Host, Alistair Innes and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
Moderated by Geoffrey Robertson, this program examines, by means of hypothetical situations, the role that Australia can play in meeting the challenges posed by disarmament and arms control. The program has been divided into three parts to facilitate its use by community and educational groups and to permit discussion of the various issues as they arise.
